name: Number of Provinces

similar_questions.title: Number of Connected Components in an Undirected Graph
The Earliest Moment When Everyone Become Friends

title: Number of Provinces
content:
There are n cities. Some of them are connected, while some are not. If city a is connected directly with city b, and city b is connected directly with city c, then city a is connected indirectly with city c.

A province is a group of directly or indirectly connected cities and no other cities outside of the group.

You are given an n x n matrix isConnected where isConnected[i][j] = 1 if the ith city and the jth city are directly connected, and isConnected[i][j] = 0 otherwise.

Return the total number of provinces.

 

Example 1:

Input: isConnected = [[1,1,0],[1,1,0],[0,0,1]]
Output: 2

Example 2:

Input: isConnected = [[1,0,0],[0,1,0],[0,0,1]]
Output: 3

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 200
  • n == isConnected.length
  • n == isConnected[i].length
  • isConnected[i][j] is 1 or 0.
  • isConnected[i][i] == 1
  • isConnected[i][j] == isConnected[j][i]

discussion_posts.name: krazyfox
discussion_posts.content: Who else hate Matrix Representation Adjacency are way better

discussion_posts.name: CIement
discussion_posts.content:
# Explanation

I'm writing this for anyone having truble to understand the input of this problem, like I had.

As the problem says `isConnected[i][j] EQ 1 if the i-th city and the j-th city are directly connected`. isConnected is a matrix of the connection between the x-coordinate and the y-coordinate, each axis is a city.

Here is a more visual explanation of the input:

```
/**

Example 1:

isConnected = [[1,1,0],[1,1,0],[0,0,1]]

 CITY |0 1 2
------|------
     0|1 1 0 
     1|1 1 0
     2|0 0 1


Connections:
0 ► 1
1 ► 0
2 ► none


Example 2:

isConnected = [[1,0,0],[0,1,0],[0,0,1]]

 |0 1 2
-|------
0|1 0 0 
1|0 1 0
2|0 0 1


Connections:
0 ► none
1 ► none
2 ► none


Example 3: 

 |0 1 2 3
---------
0|1 1 0 0 
1|1 1 1 0
2|0 1 1 1
3|0 0 1 1


0 ► 1
1 ► 0 2
2 ► 1 3
3 ► 2

**/
```

I hope it helped you and I let you dive back into the problem to solve it !!

discussion_posts.name: wozhenaishuati
discussion_posts.content: At first glance, aren't they the same?

discussion_posts.name: chenwu
discussion_posts.content: The matrix representation is a bit confusing by looking at it. It appears to be asking to number the disjoint sets in the graph. But what it actually asks is who are forming a single disjoint set and how many disjoint sets are there. M[i][i] can simply be ignored. M[i][j] means i and j are connected.

discussion_posts.name: JosephHauter
discussion_posts.content:
input is really confusing so heres an explanation on it basically like a truth table
based on this input:
`[[1,1,0],
[1,1,0],
[0,0,1]]`

```
city |  which node city connects to
--------
0     | (connects to city 0) , (connects to city 1), (not connect to city 2) 
1     | (connects to city 0) , (connects to city 1), (not connect to city 2) 
2     | (not connect to city 0), (not connect to city 1), (connects to city 2)
```  
I hope it helps good luck on solving :D please upvote so more see it

discussion_posts.name: aakankshas
discussion_posts.content: What is the diff btw this problem and [https://leetcode.com/problems/number-of-islands/]

discussion_posts.name: henrique
discussion_posts.content:
The definition of a circle given in the statement is not the one the judge uses. This comes from a wrong definition of undirect friendship. Please someone fix this soon!

In fact, it is never said that two people that share an undirect friend also are undirect friends.

Let's go through an example:  A-B-C-D. In this example, A and D are not friends (even undirectly), since they do not share a direct friend. According to the problem statement, the circles (subsets with mutual friends of maximal size) would be  A-B-C and B-C-D. However the online judger expects 1 as the correct answer.

Finding such kind of circles seems to be a much harder problem (in half an hour I could not come up with a reasonable solution), and probably is not a medium level problem.
